Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/24/22, 7/19/22 and 7/20/22. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules/statutes are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
The agency’s job description for Supervisor of Direct Care
Staff relative to required qualifications is inconsistent with
the licensing rule qualification requirements for that
position.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) (i – ii) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities.
(i) Documentation from MDHHS or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more than
30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12 months
thereafter.
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance within 30
days of the completion of the probationary period or within 180
days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
(f) One of fifteen new employees did not have an iChat
completed within 30 days prior to hire.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21)
1

(i) One of fifteen new employees did not have a Central
Registry clearance completed within 30 days prior to hire.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21 &
Interim Report 2020 CAP 10/28/20)
(j) One of fifteen new employees did not have a
probationary performance evaluation within 180 days.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21 &
Interim Report 2020 CAP 10/28/20)
R 400.4120 Supervisor of direct care workers; qualifications.
A supervisor of direct care workers shall have 1 of the following:
(a) A bachelor's degree from an accredited college or
university and 2 years of work experience in a child
caring institution.
(a) One new supervisor with bachelor’s degree worked as a
security officer in a detention facility in another state for 4
years. However, prior to hire, the facility did not determine
if that detention facility was a child caring institution. It
also could not be determined if the supervisor’s previous
work experience involved providing direct care to children,
which is the intent of this rule.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21)
2

R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person
whose function is covered by these rules has participated in
a minimum of 50 clock hours of planned training within the
first year of employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of
training annually thereafter related to the employee’s job
function. At least 16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year
shall be orientation provided prior to the assumption of duties.
One of six seasoned employees had less than 25 hours
of training in 2021.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21)
R 400.4146 Immunizations.
(2) If documentation of immunizations is unavailable,
immunizations shall begin within 30 calendar days of admission,
unless a statement from a physician indicating that
immunizations are contraindicated is included in the resident’s
record.
Upon admission, one of eight youths was overdue for a
Meningococcal vaccine since 7/8/20. Her immunization
record indicated she still has not received the vaccine. She
was admitted to Calumet on 4/18/22. The vaccine should
have been administered within 30 days of her admission.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(a) Name, address, birth date, sex, gender, race, height,
weight, hair color, eye color, identifying marks, religious
preference, and school status.
(c) A brief description of the resident’s preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the
time of admission.
3

(d) Name, address and marital status of parents and name
and address of legal guardian, if known.
(a) On the initial documentation, one of eight youth’s
weight and identifying marks were left blank on the face
sheet.
(c) The resident’s preparation for placement was
consistently answered improperly for all eight youth.
Rather than indicate how Calumet staff oriented the youths
to the facility, some indicated how other agency workers
may or may not have prepared the youths for placement
and others indicated no one prepared the youth.
(d) The marital status of one of eight youth’s parents was
left blank on the face sheet.
R 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary service
plans.
Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall be developed
for each resident. The plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for care.
(b) An assessment of the resident’s immediate and specific
needs.
(c) The specific services to be provided by the institution.
(d) Other resources to meet the resident’s needs.
One of four youths was missing a preliminary service plan.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21 &
Interim Report 2020 CAP 10/28/20)
R 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every 15
calendar days thereafter, an institution shall complete a written
service plan. The service plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
4

(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those needs are
unmet.
Three of four youths were missing eight service plans
within 30 days after admission.
One was missing a 60-day and 75-day plan.
Another was missing a 45-day, 60-day and 75-day plan.
A third was missing a 30-day, 75-day and 90-day plan.
Some completed plans were missing the date of completion
on the signature line.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21)
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
(1) (a – f) One of eight youths was missing a discharge
plan.
(a) Two of eight youths were missing the new location of
the child.
5

(f) Two of eight youths were missing the name and official
title of the person to whom the resident was discharged.
(Repeat Violation – Renewal Report 2021 CAP 9/15/21 &
Interim Report 2020 CAP 10/28/20)
2.) The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R. 400.4113 Employee Records
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing training
The facility is advised when rehiring employees who have been away for over 6 months,
the employee should be considered a new hire and all clearances, pre-hire paperwork,
and staff orientation and training must be redone.
V. CONSULTATION
The following discussions occurred with recommendations made to the Chief
Administrator:
1) The agency’s plan to merge Calumet Center youth with Lincoln Center youth at
the Lincoln Center location in August 2022.
2) I recommended the need for incident reports to identify what de-escalation
techniques were used by staff prior to a restraint, the name of the restraint and
protective technique(s) used and the debriefing that occurred after a restraint. I
recommended adding prompts to staff written statements to generate more
information about what led to the event and how staff responded.
3) I advised the facility that the supervisor who does not qualify must be demoted
immediately.
4) I provided clarification regarding policy revisions that may be needed related to
the rule addendum effective 5/30/22, and the difference between the addendum
and the new rules that are still pending.
The following discussions occurred with recommendations made to the Clinical Director:
6

5) I recommended wording changes to the youth face sheet so that the questions
align with licensing rule requirements of R 400.4152 Initial Documentation.
6) Ideas were exchanged related to possible corrective action for missing service
plans in the detention program.
7) I recommended that revised policies include the date of the revision on the
policy.
The following recommendation was made to the Center Director:
8) I recommended supervisors be reminded to leave no blank spaces on the form
when completing youth face sheets.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Calumet Center is a secure juvenile detention and treatment facility that accepts youths
referred by the Care Management Organization (CMO), MDHHS Juvenile Division and
various Courts. Their capacity is 88 and current census is 26. The staff to resident ratio
is 1:5. Since the last licensing period, there has been a significant reduction in restraints
from 72 to 24, and seclusions from 37 to 14.
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or child abuse
and/or neglect during this licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
SIR 2022C0207019 intake 1/31/22; CAP appr 4/18/22 involved a supervisor punching at
a youth during an altercation. It was unclear if the punch connected with the youth but a
written statement from the youth indicated it did. The corrective action plan included
terminating the supervisor and retraining staff on crisis intervention procedures with an
emphasis on prohibiting the use of corporal punishment.
SIR 2022C0108014 intake 2/17/22; CAP appr 3/17/2022 involved a staff person
throwing two punches toward an 18-year-old youth’s face and chest. Once the staff and
youth were separated, the staff reapproached the youth twice more, swinging at him a
third time and provoking the youth with his presence. The corrective action plan
included terminating the staff and retraining remaining staff on crisis intervention
procedures with an emphasis on prohibiting the use of corporal punishment.
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans unrelated to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2022C0207017 intake 1/21/22; CAP appr 4/26/22 involved inaccurate information
and untimely submission of a restraint report. The corrective action plan included
7

facility managers being retrained on incident report writing with an emphasis on timely
and accurate reporting.
SIR 2022C0207023 intake 3/10/22; CAP appr 5/31/22 involved a staff person delaying
calling for assistance and failing to separate two youth who were fighting. The staff
person was suspended for three days for not providing continuous line of sight and
untimely response to the fight. The staff was supervised daily for a month. Staff and
supervisors were retrained on calling for and responding to calls for assistance.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
